chapter.title: Adding User Authentication to Applications

note.para: This section is meant primarily for &PRODUCTABBR; developers.

chapter.para: &PRODUCTABBR; requires unauthenticated users to sign in before using &PRODUCTABBR; applications and services. This authentication is performed through an integrated process in which the &PRODUCTABBR; identity provider uses SAML to interact with an education organization's existing directory services and/or single-sign on (SSO) solution. After authentication, a user has an established session with &PRODUCTABBR; and can use one or more applications that share the tokens for that session.

Whenever your application uses REST API resources to interact with the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service, it must do so on behalf of an authenticated user. &PRODUCTABBR; does not allow anonymous access to the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service. It's important that your application is compliant with the &COMPANYABBR; Terms of Use and Privacy Policy.
The sections that follow cover the key tasks your application performs with regards to user authentication with links to more detailed &PRODUCTABBR; documentation.

section.title: User Authentication Process Overview
section.para: &PRODUCTABBR; uses SAML to communicate with an education organization's IDP to authenticate a user and generate an OAuth token for the API session. The process is displayed in the following diagram:

figure.title: An Overview of the OAuth Application Workflow

section.para: The steps outlined above are as follows:

step.para: OAuth/Authorize - The client's application server redirects to the &PRODUCTABBR; API to request user authentication.
(optional) Realm Discovery - If a realm has not already been provided, the user will be prompted to select a realm.

SAML Request - The API sends a SAML request for user authentication through the browser to the education organization's identity provider (IDP). Note: If the user does not already have an existing API session, then &PRODUCTABBR; will force authentication.
Login - The user logs in to the education organization's identity provider.

SAML Assertion - If authenticated, the education organization's identity provider sends a SAML assertion through the browser that includes the user's authentication attributes to the &PRODUCTABBR; API.
Return OAuth Code - The API returns the authorization code to the application.
OAuth/Token - The application sends a request to the API with its authorization code and other attributes to generate a token for the API session.

section.para: The token is then used for subsequent API calls and is valid for the application's session.
Note: Steps 1, 6, and 7 are all part of the OAuth 2.0 authentication process. For more information on OAuth 2.0, please see the documentation for the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework.

section.title: Signing In, Creating Sessions
section.para: &COMPANYABBR; has documented how authentication works in . Included are examples of SAML interactions such as those your application will need to have with an education organization's identity provider. When planning how your application authenticates users, use that documentation as your primary resource.

note.para: &COMPANYABBR; recommends using a third-party OAuth 2.0 client library, many of which are freely available in a variety of programming languages.

section.para: While that documentation is comprehensive, providing details you'll need to have for your design and implementation, it doesn't narrow down what the authentication process looks like from the developers' perspective. For that, see the process described here:

listitem.para: When a user first tries to use an &PRODUCTABBR; application, or when a user's session times out, &PRODUCTABBR; must authenticate the user using the OAuth 2.0 protocol. The application first redirects the user's browser to the &RESTAPI; (behavior compliant with OAuth 2.0 standard).
There are three arguments passed in this call:
response_type - Currently, the only supported response type is code.
client_id - This is the client ID value of your application, assigned by &COMPANYABBR; when you registered the application.

Besides these three arguments, the redirect call can also include a state parameter, which can be set to anything the application wants, and which is returned as a parameter in the callback.
The &PRODUCTABBR; API takes control of the authentication process for the next step.

After the user authenticates, the &RESTAPI; uses the redirect_uri (provided in the previous call) to pass the OAuth verification code back to the application (behavior compliant with OAuth 2.0 standard).
At this point, the application takes control of the authentication process.

After the user's authentication is verified, the application uses the OAuth verification code to obtain a session token for use in calls to the &RESTAPI;. This is a standard OAuth 2.0 call. section.title: Using Authorization Tokens During a Session
section.para: After establishing a session, an application should use the current, active OAuth authorization token in its HTTP header for each &RESTAPI; request during that session. This is the same process you used in forming calls through a REST client as described in .

section.title: Signing Out
section.para: &PRODUCTABBR; applications handle signing out as follows:

listitem.para: When a user signs out of &PRODUCTABBR;, typically from an application interface, that user's session is terminated only from &PRODUCTABBR;. The session that user has with the education organization's identity provider remains, even though that session is no longer shared by the &PRODUCTABBR; application.

After signing out from an &PRODUCTABBR; application, the user must sign in again to use that application. This is true whether or not there's a valid session with the education organization's identity provider. The application checks for an existing identity provider session upon login and creates the new tokens for a new &PRODUCTABBR; session.

section.title: Timing Out
section.para: Each identity provider has a configurable timeout period that controls the lifespan of its own tokens. The &PRODUCTABBR; identity provider also has a session timeout, which causes an error code response to any REST API calls made with that token following the timeout threshold. The timeout threshold is 1 hour for Sandbox mode and 20 minutes for Production mode. The &PRODUCTABBR; identity provider extends its timeout with each API call so that sessions last for a certain number of minutes past the last call. Then a timeout occurs, the application should redirect the user to sign in as if it was a first attempt.

section.title: Handling Response Codes, Including Errors
section.para: Ensure that your application handles errors gracefully. For example, an HTTP 404 response code should indicate to the user that the requested results do not exist, while an HTTP 401 should indicate that the user isn't authorized to view the requested results.
